natural problem: What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$.
natural solution: If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "average (setsum f {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124}) = 44"
shows  "average (setsum f {n. n \<ge> 5 powr 3 \<and> n \<le> 8 powr 2}) = 44"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "average (setsum f {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124}) = 44"
shows  "average (setsum f {n. n \<ge> 5 powr 3 \<and> n \<le> 8 powr 2}) = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose there is a function $f$ that returns the same number for all integers $n$ between 25 and 124 inclusive. If the average value of $f(n)$ for all $n$ in this range is 44, then the average value of $f(n)$ for all $n$ between $5^3$ and $8^2$ inclusive is also 44.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>i\<in>{i. i \<ge> 5^2 \<and> i < 5^3 \<and> i \<ge> 8^1 \<and> i < 8^2}. i) / card {i. i \<ge> 5^2 \<and> i < 5^3 \<and> i \<ge> 8^1 \<and> i < 8^2}"
shows  "avg = 44"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>i\<in>{i. i \<ge> 5^2 \<and> i < 5^3 \<and> i \<ge> 8^1 \<and> i < 8^2}. i) / card {i. i \<ge> 5^2 \<and> i < 5^3 \<and> i \<ge> 8^1 \<and> i < 8^2}"
shows  "avg = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the average of the set of numbers that are greater than or equal to 25 and less than 125, and also greater than or equal to 8 and less than 64. The final answer is 44.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes average :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 5 = n div 8)"
shows  "average n = 44"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44

 *)

theorem
fixes average :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 5 = n div 8)"
shows  "average n = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the average value of $n$ such that it satisfies the condition $n \div 5 = n \div 8$ for all integers $n$ between 25 and 124 (inclusive). The final answer is 44.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a < 8 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b < 8 \<and> n = 8 * a + b"
shows  "average {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> (\<exists> a b. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a < 8 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b < 8 \<and> n = 8 * a + b)} = 44"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a < 8 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b < 8 \<and> n = 8 * a + b"
shows  "average {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> (\<exists> a b. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a < 8 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b < 8 \<and> n = 8 * a + b)} = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the average of all natural numbers between 25 and 124, inclusive, that can be expressed as the sum of multiples of 8, where both multiples are non-negative integers less than 8. The final answer is 44.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> n \<in> nat"
and h1 : "avg = (sum id {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> n \<in> nat}) / card {n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> n \<in> nat}"
shows  "avg = 44"

 *)

shows  "avg = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the average of all natural numbers between 25 and 124 inclusive? The final answer is 44.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "average = (\<Sum>i | i \<ge> 5 powr 2 \<and> i < 5 powr 3 \<and> i \<ge> 8 powr 1 \<and> i < 8 powr 2. i) / card {i | i \<ge> 5 powr 2 \<and> i < 5 powr 3 \<and> i \<ge> 8 powr 1 \<and> i < 8 powr 2}"
shows  "average = 44"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44

 *)

fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "average = (\<Sum>i | i \<ge> 5 powr 2 \<and> i < 5 powr 3 \<and> i \<ge> 8 powr 1 \<and> i < 8 powr 2. i) / card {i | i \<ge> 5 powr 2 \<and> i < 5 powr 3 \<and> i \<ge> 8 powr 1 \<and> i < 8 powr 2}"
shows  "average = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 8 \<and> n \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> n \<ge> 8 \<and> n \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
shows  "average (set (map f [25..124])) = 44"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 8 \<and> n \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124 \<and> n \<ge> 8 \<and> n \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f n = n"
shows  "average (set (map f [25..124])) = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined such that for all integers $n$ in the range of 25 to 124, $f(n) = n$. The same function $f$ also holds that for all integers $n$ in the range of 8 to 63, $f(n) = n$. If these two conditions are satisfied simultaneously, what is the average value of $f(n)$ for all $n$ between 25 and 124? The final answer is 44.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {x. x \<in> {100\<^sub>5..444\<^sub>5} \<and> x \<in> {10\<^sub>8..77\<^sub>8}}"
shows  "average n = 44"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {x. x \<in> {100\<^sub>5..444\<^sub>5} \<and> x \<in> {10\<^sub>8..77\<^sub>8}}"
shows  "average n = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the average of a natural number $n$ that lies in the range of $100_5$ to $444_5$ and also in the range of $10_8$ to $77_8$. The final answer is 44.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<lambda> s. sum id s div card s)"
and h1 : "finite {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 500 \<and> 10 \<le> n \<and> n < 100}"
shows  "avg {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 500 \<and> 10 \<le> n \<and> n < 100} = 44"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<lambda> s. sum id s div card s)"
and h1 : "finite {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 500 \<and> 10 \<le> n \<and> n < 100}"
shows  "avg {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 500 \<and> 10 \<le> n \<and> n < 100} = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the average of all natural numbers $n$ such that $10 \leq n < 100$ and $100 \leq n < 500$. The final answer is 44.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 5 \<ge> 10 \<and> n div 5 \<le> 99)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 8 \<ge> 10 \<and> n div 8 \<le> 99)"
and h2 : "avg = (\<Sum>n=25..124. n) / 100"
shows  "avg = 44"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have three digits when written in base $5$, but two digits when written in base $8$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 44
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has three digits in base $5$, then $5^2\le n<5^3$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $8$, then $8^1\le n<8^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{25,26,27,28,\ldots,61,62,63\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{25+63}{2} = \boxed{44}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 5 \<ge> 10 \<and> n div 5 \<le> 99)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. (n \<ge> 25 \<and> n \<le> 124) \<longrightarrow> (n div 8 \<ge> 10 \<and> n div 8 \<le> 99)"
and h2 : "avg = (\<Sum>n=25..124. n) / 100"
shows  "avg = 44"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider all integers from 25 to 124 inclusive. If each of these numbers divided by 5 or 8 results in a number between 10 and 99 inclusive, what is the average of these numbers? The final answer is 44.
